title: How to use 'etc.' properly (grammar, writing, redundancy, and English) - Quora

response.answer_text: Et cetera is Latin for “and the rest.” It is properly used to end what would be a string of similar items in a logical continuation that the reader could easily surmise without seeing the entire list. Here are some examples: “The children had not yet picked up all their toys: dolls, blocks, train cars, train tracks, stuffed animals, board games, etc.”; “Susan has any number of dresses she could wear — short, knee-length, maxi, red, blue, black, etc.”; and “Carol was an aficionado of all music: classical, jazz, country, etc.”

Using etc. in a sentence: The food pantry needs staples like beans, canned goods, evaporated milk, pasta, bottled water, etc. to give to people who are in need or homeless. Etc. is typically used to mean, “and so forth,” to indicate continuing a long list in a similar vein.
